Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Combined AFM and Fluorescence Microscopy System
Award.AbstractNarration:
1337586
Smith, Steve

This award from the Major Instrumentation program supports South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSM&T) with the acquisition of a Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) optimized for the study of biomaterials in aqueous environments, in combination with an inverted frame fluorescence microscope, suitable for simultaneous topographic and fluorescence imaging. This instrument will be used in research to correlate the optical and electronic properties of biomaterials with nanometer scale topography. The project will be the nexus for collaborative science undertaken by a diverse group of Physicists, Chemists, Biologists and Chemical Engineers, with broad scientific, educational and societal impacts. The instrument will also enable and support studies on many other soft materials, which may be immersed in liquids, and permit simultaneous and correlative fluorescence imaging. The instrumentation will be unique in the State of South Dakota, and will support several new graduate and undergraduate programs at SDSM&T, including undergraduate and graduate programs in nanotechnology, applied biology, bio-chemistry and bio-physics. The instrument will facilitate collaboration across the SDSM&T campus and with South Dakota State University. Many students in South Dakota will be exposed to the proposed research, thus broadening the educational impacts. SDSM&T also maintains a permanent Native American outreach program, with established and well-organized outreach programs such as SD GEAR UP, aimed at increasing the number of Native American high-school students continuing on to college. On-going results of the project would be incorporated into the educational portions of this program.

OVERVIEW: The goal of NSF project DMR-13375886 was to acquire an Atomic Force Microscope combined with a fluorescence microscope in order to support a growing need to probe and correlate the optical and electronic properties of bio-materials with nanometer scale structure readily obtainable using AFM. The instrumentation has been utilized to probe and correlate the optical and electronic properties of nano- and bio-materials with the nanometer scale structure readily obtainable using AFM. Research to date spans the study of endocytosis in macrophages, imaging carbohydrate binding modules and their interaction with cellulose substrates, the imaging of single molecules of DNA, the interaction of nano-structures which modify the photonic density of states to control fluorescence of inorganic nano-materials, and other applications which benefit from the unique capabilities offered by this instrumentation.

Intellectual merit: The research topics the acquired instrumentation has been utilized for in the first year since its installation are important scientifically in the areas of cell biology, bio-physics, plant and animal science, and optics and photonics. The AFM / Fluorescence study of endocytosis in macrophages has increased our understanding of how clathrin mediated endocytosis controls the invagination of foreign cargo, a key step in immune response. By imaging carbohydrate binding modules, a key component of all cellulase enzymes, and their interaction with cellulose substrates, the specificity of their corresponding enzyme or enzyme complex can be understood in terms of the structure of the enzyme and the target; the imaging of single molecules of DNA will provide information regarding the relation of the conformation of DNA to genetic diseases; and explaining how the interaction of nano-structures with optical fields can modify the photonic density of states to control fluorescence of inorganic nano-materials can lead to new insights into the limits of these materials in energy and display technologies.

Broader Impact: The research outcomes and findings contribute to the advancement of human health, by studying the mechanisms which govern immune response and genetic disorders; they provide advances in energy production by studying how cellulase enzymes and their components work to break-down cellulose to simple sugars, which can be fermented to produce bio-fuels; and contribute towards improving energy-efficiency by paving the way for improved light emitting devices with higher efficiency. In terms of training and workforce development, students, postdocs and faculty from SDSMT have been trained in operating this instrumentation, and engaged in collaborative research with researchers at multiple institutes across the State of South Dakota and the Nation. The instrumentation allowed the participants to contribute to an outreach program for Native American pre-college students known as GEARUP. The Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduates Program (GEARUP), whose mission is to increase the number of American Indian students that achieve success in higher education, focusing on matriculation and retention from 8th-to-9th grade and 12th grade-to-college.
